question: You think "I should study" but can't seem to start.
explanation: This kind of procrastination is not "laziness". There is a view that it is a natural reaction to avoid discomfort. First, it is okay not to blame yourself for not starting.

best_for: People who tend to blame themselves for procrastinating
limitations: Chronic lack of motivation may require a different approach
expanded_details.citation_role: Supports the emotion regulation model of procrastination through observational research

question: When you wait for "motivation to kick in" before starting, what tends to happen?
choices: Motivation doesn't come and time just passes
You relax and become more efficient
explanation: Motivation has been reported to "come after you start" rather than being something you "wait for." This is called behavioral activation. ("Naturally emerging" and "relaxing for efficiency" are rare — waiting usually doesn't help.)

best_for: People who wait a long time for motivation
limitations: When genuinely tired, rest is needed
expanded_details.citation_role: Explains behavioral activation theory in procrastination research

question: What method has been reported to lower the barrier to starting studying?
choices: Decide "just 10 seconds" and open your materials
Set up an environment for long concentration
explanation: Even "starting" for 10 seconds tends to make it easier to switch into the task. Ending at 10 seconds is fine. Try a different method if it doesn't work. Try it just once. ("Setting up the environment" and "waiting for motivation" take too long.)
actionable_advice: 💡 Next time you can't start studying, try "just open your materials for 10 seconds."

limitations: When genuinely tired, rest is needed
If you can't move even for 10 seconds, don't force it
expanded_details.citation_role: Indirectly supports the 10-second rule from procrastination research
expanded_details.try_this: Try "just open your materials for 10 seconds"

tiny_metric.before_prompt: How much do you "not want to" right now? (0-10)
tiny_metric.stop_rule: If no change or it increases, retreat for today

question: Deciding in advance "When X happens, I'll do Y" tends to increase follow-through.
explanation: This is called "implementation intention" or "If-Then planning." Example: "After dinner, I'll sit at my desk." Research has reported higher follow-through rates compared to having no plan.

best_for: People who plan but can't execute
People who want to build habits
limitations: Less effective if the trigger is vague
expanded_details.citation_role: Research directly testing the effect of implementation intention (If-Then planning)

question: When you can't start studying, which fits you best?
choices: Freeze trying to do it perfectly
explanation: All are valid answers. Noticing your pattern tends to make it easier to choose the right strategy.

question: When using "If-Then planning," which format is easiest to follow through on?
choices: Decide in the format "When X (trigger), I'll do Y (action)"
explanation: Setting a trigger (when/where) paired with an action (what to do) tends to make execution more automatic. Try it just once. ("Try harder" and "someday" are too vague to follow through on.)
actionable_advice: 💡 Set one If-Then for today: "When X happens, I'll open my materials for just 10 seconds"

best_for: People whose plans tend to fall through
People who want to build habits
limitations: Less effective if the trigger isn't part of daily routine
expanded_details.citation_role: Indirectly supports the specific format of implementation intention
expanded_details.try_this: Set one: "When X happens, I'll open my materials for 10 seconds"

tiny_metric.before_prompt: Did you execute your If-Then this week?
tiny_metric.success_rule: Even once a week is OK
tiny_metric.stop_rule: If you can't execute for 2 weeks, try a different method

comparator.cost: 30 seconds to plan / 10 seconds to execute

fallback.next: Use "When I feel like checking my phone" as the trigger

question: There's a view that procrastination isn't just about "weak willpower."
explanation: Research reports that procrastination is often caused by "avoidance of discomfort" or "task ambiguity" rather than willpower. Addressing it through systems tends to work better than blaming yourself.

best_for: People who tend to blame themselves
People who rely too much on willpower
limitations: Not all procrastination has the same cause
expanded_details.citation_role: Supports the emotion regulation model of procrastination

question: What's an easy way to reduce the "environmental friction" of starting to study?
choices: Leave your study materials open on your desk
Set up the perfect environment before starting
explanation: The less effort it takes to "get started," the more likely action is to occur. Leaving materials open can lower the starting barrier. Try it just once. ("Perfect environment" and "waiting for motivation" tend to lead to more procrastination.)
actionable_advice: 💡 Before bed tonight, leave tomorrow's study materials open on your desk.

best_for: People who spend too much time setting up their environment
limitations: Can backfire in a messy environment
expanded_details.citation_role: Indirectly supports the link between environmental friction and action initiation
expanded_details.try_this: 👉 Before starting to study → open your materials and place them on your desk for just 10 seconds

tiny_metric.before_prompt: Were the materials open in the morning?
tiny_metric.after_prompt: If open, were you able to start studying?
tiny_metric.success_rule: Starting with them open is OK
tiny_metric.stop_rule: If no effect after a week, stop

fallback.when: No space to leave materials out
fallback.next: Put the study app on your phone's home screen

question: Of the techniques you learned today, which could you use starting tomorrow?
explanation: All are worth trying. If one doesn't work, try another. That's learning too. Try it just once. ("All" is fine but don't push yourself — start with just one.)
actionable_advice: 💡 Try just once tomorrow: when you can't start studying, "just open your materials for 10 seconds."

best_for: People who want to start new habits
limitations: Can be easy to forget without practice
expanded_details.try_this: Use "just open my materials for 10 seconds" once tomorrow

tiny_metric.metric: Did you manage to use it at least once this week?
tiny_metric.stop_rule: If you can't use it for a week, stop

fallback.next: Shrink to the minimum task (solve just 1 problem)

question: Were the "how to start studying" techniques from this lesson likely to be useful for you?
explanation: All answers are valid. If it "didn't feel like a fit," exploring a different approach is also important. Procrastination has different causes for different people, so the process of finding what works for you is itself valuable.
